content: How can I help you today?

Well, my partner thought it was a good idea for me to see a therapist because I haven’t been able to sleep lately. Honestly, I’m not sure how much this will help, but I have a lot on my mind, mostly about work. I’m worried I might lose my job, and it’s been keeping me up at night.

Thank you for sharing what’s been going on for you. It sounds like there’s a lot weighing on you, especially with work and concerns about your job. Not being able to sleep and having your mind race with worries can feel overwhelming. What’s been the hardest part for you in dealing with all of this?

I think the hardest part is just not being able to turn my brain off. As soon as I try to go to bed, all these thoughts about work come rushing in—what if I mess something up? What if they fire me and I can’t take care of my kids? It’s like I’m stuck in this loop I can’t get out of.

It sounds exhausting, trying to rest but feeling trapped in a cycle of worry. Those thoughts about work and providing for your kids seem really important to you, and it shows how much you care about doing well for them. How do you usually cope when these thoughts feel overwhelming?

Honestly, I don’t think I’ve been coping all that well. I’ll sometimes scroll through my phone or watch something to try to distract myself, but it doesn’t really help. Most of the time, I just lie there, overthinking everything until I eventually crash from sheer exhaustion. It’s frustrating because I don’t feel like I know how to make it stop.

It sounds like you're doing what you can to get through those tough moments, even if it doesn’t feel like enough. It must be frustrating to keep searching for relief but still find yourself stuck in those loops. Have there ever been times, even small ones, when you felt you were able to quiet your mind or find a bit of peace?

Not really, to be honest. Sometimes I’ll feel distracted for a little while if I’m really caught up in playing with my kids or running errands, but once I’m alone or it’s time to go to bed, it all comes back. It feels like there’s no real escape from it.

That feeling of no escape sounds incredibly heavy, especially when it follows you into quiet moments or bedtime. It seems like those moments of distraction—playing with your kids or staying busy—give you at least a temporary break. What’s important to you about being able to find more peace, especially when it's time to rest?

Well, I think being able to rest would help me be more present for my family. I feel like I’m always exhausted and short-tempered, and I hate that they see me like this. I just want to be a better parent and partner, but it’s hard when I’m running on empty.

It takes a lot of strength to recognize how much you care about being fully there for your family, even while facing exhaustion and struggle. Wanting to be a better parent and partner really says a lot about your dedication to them. What do you think might need to change to help you feel more rested and present for those moments?

Honestly, I don’t even know where to start. I mean, maybe if I could figure out how to stop stressing so much about work, that would help. But it feels like that's impossible because I can’t control what’s going to happen, you know?

Feeling like you can't control what might happen at work can definitely make it harder to let go of those worries. It sounds like finding a way to ease that stress could make a big difference for you, but it also feels overwhelming to figure out how. What would it mean for you to approach this one small step at a time?

I guess taking things one step at a time might make it more manageable, but I don’t even know what the first step would be. Everything with work feels out of my hands, and that’s what gets to me the most. Maybe figuring out how to not let it take over my whole day could be a start.

Focusing on keeping work stress from taking over your day sounds like a thoughtful first step. It shows you're open to exploring ways to create some balance in your life, even though things at work feel out of your control. Is there anything you’ve done in the past, even small, that helped bring a sense of calm or focus during tough times?

Not really, no. I’ve mostly just tried to push through things or distract myself, but that’s not working anymore. I feel like I don’t have the energy or tools to figure out how to calm myself down. Honestly, I don’t know where to even begin.

It sounds like you've been doing your best to push forward, even when it feels like you're running on empty. That takes resilience, even if it feels like it’s not working right now. You don’t have to figure this out all at once, and if it feels overwhelming, we can explore small, practical ways to start building that sense of calm over time. Would you like to talk about what that first small step could look like?

It sounds like you've been doing your best to deal with a really challenging situation, even when it feels like you're stuck. Sometimes the first step can be the smallest thing, like creating a moment in your day to just breathe or pause for yourself. Would you be open to trying something simple like that to start?

It sounds like you've been doing your best to deal with a really challenging situation, even when it feels like you're stuck. Sometimes the first step can be the smallest thing, like creating a moment in your day to just breathe or pause for yourself. Would you be open to trying something simple like that to start?
Yeah, I guess I could try that. I’m not sure if it’ll help, but I’m willing to give it a shot. I just don’t really know how to start or if I’d even be doing it right.

It's understandable to feel unsure about starting something new. The good thing is, there's no one "right" way—it’s more about what feels manageable and helpful for you. Taking even a minute to pause, focus on your breathing, or reflect could be a step toward feeling calmer. Would practicing something like that for a short time feel doable for you? Or would you prefer to explore other small ways to create space in your day?
